summary: This is a motion in limine filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team seeking to exclude evidence related to 'Accuser-3' from her criminal trial. The motion argues that Accuser-3 was above the age of consent in the UK (16) during the alleged encounters in 1994-1995, that she cannot establish she was a minor during alleged travel to the US, and therefore her testimony does not prove illegal conduct relevant to the charged Mann Act conspiracies. The defense contends the evidence is inadmissible under Federal Rules of Evidence 404(b) and 403, and alternatively requests limiting instructions.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, accused of conspiring with Jeffrey Epstein to entice minors to travel for illegal sexual activity. Her defense team is filing this motion to exclude evidence.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier alleged to have sexually abused Accuser-3. The motion argues the alleged sex acts with Accuser-3 were not illegal as she was above the UK age of consent.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP representing Ghislaine Maxwell, signed the motion.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C. listed as counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C. listed as counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Stemheim
persons.context: Attorney from Law Offices of Bobbi C. Stemheim listed as counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Accuser-3
persons.context: An individual described in the indictment as 'Minor Victim-3'. The defense motion argues she was not a minor under UK law during alleged encounters with Epstein in London and her testimony should be excluded.

persons.name: Accuser-1
persons.context: Referenced as one of the other accusers in the indictment, distinct from Accuser-3.

persons.name: Accuser-2
persons.context: Referenced as one of the other accusers in the indictment, distinct from Accuser-3.

connections.description: Alleged by the government to have conspired to entice minors to travel for illegal sexual activity. The motion disputes that evidence related to Accuser-3 proves this conspiracy.
The indictment alleges Maxwell groomed and befriended Accuser-3, introduced her to Epstein, and encouraged her to massage Epstein knowing it would lead to sex acts.
The indictment alleges Epstein sexually abused Accuser-3. The defense argues the acts were not illegal as she was above the age of consent.
Everdell is one of the lead attorneys filing this motion on behalf of defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.
Pagliuca is listed as defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell.
Menninger is listed as defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell.
Stemheim is listed as defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Alleged grooming and abuse of Accuser-3 begins
events.description: The indictment alleges Maxwell groomed and befriended Accuser-3 in London, introduced her to Epstein, and arranged interactions leading to alleged sexual abuse by Epstein.

events.title: Original indictment filed
events.description: The original indictment against Ghislaine Maxwell was filed, including allegations related to Accuser-3.

events.title: First superseding indictment filed
events.description: The S1 Superseding Indictment was filed, repeating allegations related to Accuser-3.

events.title: Court opinion on motion to strike
events.description: The court issued an opinion and order denying Maxwell's motion to strike allegations about Accuser-3 from the indictment, reserving the issue for trial.

events.title: Motion in limine filed
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team files this motion in limine to exclude evidence related to Accuser-3.

keyFacts: The defense argues 'Accuser-3' was above the legal age of consent in the United Kingdom (16 years old) during the alleged sexual encounters with Jeffrey Epstein in London in 1994-1995, meaning the alleged acts were not illegal under UK law.

The defense states the government concedes Accuser-3 cannot establish she was a minor (under 18) when she allegedly first traveled to the United States at Epstein and Maxwell's invitation, or when she allegedly engaged in sex acts with Epstein in the US.

The motion claims the government originally included Accuser-3's allegations in the indictment under the mistaken belief she was a minor, and repeated this error in the S2 Superseding Indictment after the defense pointed out the age-of-consent issue.

The defense seeks to preclude the government and Accuser-3 from referring to her as a 'minor' or stating she was 'sexually abused' by Epstein, arguing these terms are misleading and prejudicial as the alleged conduct was legal.

If the evidence is admitted, the defense requests a limiting instruction informing the jury that the alleged sexual activity in London was not illegal under UK law and cannot be considered 'illegal,' 'criminal,' or 'unlawful' for the purposes of the charged crimes.
